featureType.name: qgis_irmt_0c7902da_535c_4dea_95c5_6a241d78f2bf
featureType.title: SoVI-BC_SAC_5_Version1
featureType.abstract: The Geological Survey of Canada (GSC) is working in partnership with the Global Earthquake Model Foundation (GEM) to develop a regional multi-level Social Vulnerability (SoVI) model for British Columbia. Outputs will be incorporated into an integrated earthquake risk assessment for the Province of British Columbia. The SoVI-BC model reflects underlying socioeconomic drivers of risk for 7 distinct community archetypes: 1. Urban Metropolitan Centre 2. Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with administrative subdivisions 3. Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with no administrative subdivisions 4. Exurban Regional District with strong metropolitan influence 5. Exurban Regional District with moderate metropolitan influence 6. Rural District with weak metropolitan influence 7. Rural District with no metropolitan influence There are separate SoVI models for each of these 7 community archetypes. Each regional SoVI model is defined in terms of four major system components: A. Social System (20 variables: age, family characteristics, language, education, etc.) B. Economic System (16 variables: household income, individual income, employment status, etc.) C. Community Health (13 variables: illness, access to health care, quality of life, etc.) D. Built Environment (4 variables: seismic safety level, proximity to essential facilities) We have run PCA on each of the 4 model components for all 7 community typologies to get weightings that we will assign in our multi-level hierarchical model. Version 1 of the SoVI-BC model is now ready in draft mode for review and comment. We welcome your input on model design and suggestions for improvement.
